title: Can I sue a dead person or his estate for personal injury claim?
question: Hi, I was in car injury. It was not my fault. The guy was at fault 100%. I've been in therapy. He was 81 and I recently learned he died over a year ago. The two year the statue of limitation for the accident is only a month away. The insurance company is not compensating me properly for my pain and suffering. Can I file a lawsuit? I just read online that the time to sue deceased person is 1 year in CA. What are my options? Thank you very much in advance for your answers!
answers:
Some applicable law to the statute/rules/procedures/etc. for suing after the death of the "defendant" are as follows:

“If a person against whom an action may be brought on a liability of the person, whether arising in contract, tort, or otherwise, and whether accrued or not accrued, dies before the expiration of the applicable limitations period, and the cause of action survives, an action may be commenced within one year after the date of death, and the limitations period that would have been applicable does not apply.” California Code of Civil Procedure § 366.2(a). The predecessor of California Code of Civil Procedure § 366.2 (formerly § 353) was amended to clarify just how strictly this one-year statute of limitations shall be applied. California Code of Civil Procedure § 366.2 now provides, that the one (1) year statute of limitations governs whether the decedent’s liability arises in contract, tort or otherwise, that other statutes of limitations do not control, and that tolling provisions other than specific Probate Code provisions do not apply. The probate code also provides for claims made for the debts of a decedent and expressly incorporates the one year statute of limitations described above. California Probate Code § 13109 (“Section 366.2 of the Code of Civil Procedure applies in an action under this section.”)

I could write about ten pages or more... but if I did would have to include a table of contents and table of authorities... the law seems clear, but it has some very limited exceptions... the type of exceptions that need a lawyer to investigate for each and every case.

Fortunately, most of us personal injury types offer free consultations and take such cases on contingency no matter where the case is in California, so there is nothing to fear in calling us.

- Paul

Paul J. Molinaro, M.D., J.D.
Attorney at Law, Physician

Given the language of Cal. Code of Civil Procedure Section 366.2 below, you had better immediately contact a wrongful death attorney with expertise in probate matters.



366.2. (a) If a person against whom an action may be brought on a liability of the person, whether arising in contract, tort, or otherwise, and whether accrued or not accrued, dies before the expiration of the applicable limitations period, and the cause of action survives, an action may be commenced within one year after the date of death, and the limitations period that would have been applicable does not apply.
(b) The limitations period provided in this section for commencement of an action shall not be tolled or extended for any reason except as provided in any of the following, where applicable:
(1) Sections 12, 12a, and 12b of this code.
(2) Part 4 (commencing with Section 9000) of Division 7 of the Probate Code (creditor claims in administration of estates of decedents).
(3) Part 8 (commencing with Section 19000) of Division 9 of the Probate Code (payment of claims, debts, and expenses from revocable trust of deceased settlor).
. . .

I have dealt with this issue before. Yes the Probate Code prohibits you from suing the estate more than one year after the date of death, however, my understanding is that code does not apply to insurance liability coverage. In that case the normal statute of limitations applies.

You should have one month (or so) remaining to file. But do not wait! The insurance company likely has your claim on a one month diary and is waiting to see if you file a lawsuit. You should hire an attorney (if needed) and file soon.

The statute of limitations for suing for negligence causing personal injuries is two years presently in California. It used to be one year, but that law was changed a few years back; you are probably looking at old information on the internet. If there is one thing that I would suggest to anyone contemplating any kind of legal action in a Court in California, it is to seek the advice of an attorney, and in your case to do it right away!

I've filed a suit against the deceased or his/her heirs. But there are a lot of facts that come in to play. I would talk to a car accident attorney asap, who can help you out with strategy, paying some of your bills immediately etc. We give free consultations.
This sounds like a homework assignment. You can still file suit. See Probate Codes sections 9390 and 550 et seq.

In most cases, the one year period takes precedence over the statute of limitations. (It can be a shorter period if there was a formal probate proceeding.) There are some possible exceptions that are very specific to certain situations. You might want to discuss it with a lawyer.
Better get a lawyer now before it is too late.

I recommend getting an attorney to settle a lawsuit with the decedents insurance company or your own immediately and possibly file a lawsuit to preserve the statute of limitations if need be. It sounds complicated but us attorneys do this every day.
Do NOT wait. Contact a personal injury attorney in your state to discuss the details of your injuries as well as other issues. Check Avvo for a listing of attorneys. Good luck.
